_source.text: SPANISH CLIMATE CHANGE AND CLEAN ENERGY STRATEGY
_source.document_name: Spanish Climate Change And Clean Energy Strategy Horizon 2007- 2012 -2020
_source.document_description: The Spanish Climate Change and Clean Energy Strategy (EECCEL) horizon 2007-2012-2020 is part of the Spanish Sustainable Development Strategy (EEDS). The EECCEL includes different measures that contribute to sustainable development within the scope of climate change and clean energy.  This Strategy is based on the reference framework of the 'Spanish Strategy for the fulfilment of the objectives under the Kyoto Protocol', and it takes into account the measures and Programmes adopted by the Autonomous Communities.  The strategy has two chapters. The first one defines actions to fight against climate change and the second one, actions to achieve cleaner energy. Each chapter includes a description of the present situation, the objectives to be reached, the suggested measures and a selection of indicators for the corresponding follow-up.  The operational objectives are: - To ensure the reduction of GHG emissions in Spain, giving special importance to measures related to the energy sector. According to the national inventory, in 2005, emissions from energy process represented about 78.87% of total national emissions. - To contribute to sustainable development and the fulfilment of climate change commitments by strengthening the use of flexible project-based mechanisms. - To promote additional reduction measures in sectors concerned with diffuse pollution. - To apply the National Climate Change Adaptation Plan (NCCAP) so as to integrate adaptation measures and strategies in sectoral policies. - To increase public awareness with respect to clean energy and climate change. - To promote research, development and innovation in matters of climate change and clean energy. - To guarantee energy supply security by means of cleaner energies, mainly from renewable sources, achieving other environmental benefits (for example, air quality) and limiting the growth rate of external energy dependence. - To boost energy- and resource efficiency for companies and for end users.  The government has adopted a Plan of Urgent Measures (PMU), which together with the 2008-2012 Energy Saving and Efficiency Action Plan aims to consolidate the trend change of GHG emissions in Spain initiated in 2006.

_source.text: Climate change is one of the main threats to sustainable development, it represents one of the main environmental challenges with effects on the global economy, health and social welfare. Its impacts will be felt even more intensely by future generations. Therefore, it is necessary to act now and reduce emissions while at the same time looking for ways to adapt to the impacts of climate change. According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), in the contribution of Working Group I to the Fourth Assessment Report, approved in Paris on February 2, 2007, global warming is unequivocal and is attributed to the action of man with greater than 90% certainty. The average global temperature at the land surface has increased in the last hundred years by 0.74 [0.55 to 0.92]°C, projections indicate changes in surface temperature in the last ten years of the 21st century with respect to the last twenty years of the 20th century from a range of 1.8 to 4.0 °C, likewise, the atmospheric concentration of CO₂ has increased by 35.36% since pre-industrial times. All this translates into significant negative impacts on ecosystems and socioeconomic systems in all regions of the planet, with a significant incidence in southern Europe, according to the results of Working Group II of the Fourth Assessment Report of the IPCC approved in Brussels on last April 6, 2007. However, according to the conclusions of Working Group III adopted in Bangkok, Thailand, on May 4, a determined action that uses the technologies currently available allows achieving the stabilization objectives at a lower cost than previously planned. It is essential to adopt far-reaching measures urgently, but the solution is within reach of a determined joint will.

The first one defines actions to fight against climate change and the second one, actions to achieve cleaner energy. _source.text: Spain, due to its geographical location and its socioeconomic characteristics, is a country that is highly vulnerable to climate change, as has been made clear in the most recent evaluations and research. The serious environmental problems that are reinforced by the effect of climate change are: the decrease in water resources and the regression of the coast, the loss of biological biodiversity and natural ecosystems, and the increase in soil erosion processes. There are also other effects of climate change that will also cause serious impacts on economic sectors.

_source.text: This Strategy has as a frame of reference the "Spanish Strategy for compliance with the Kyoto Protocol" approved by the Plenary Session of the National Climate Council on February 5, 2004, and takes into account the measures and programs adopted by the Autonomous Communities in these years, some of them especially active. However, the numerous initiatives undertaken by the general administration of the state and the Autonomous Communities since that date have substantially changed the regulatory and planning framework and have allowed an evolution towards scenarios in which some changes in trend are observed. However, the emission forecasts show the need to contemplate additional measures that contribute to obtaining a scenario for sustainable economic, social and environmental development.

_source.text: This strategy is structured in two chapters, in the first, actions have been defined to fight against climate change and, in the second, to achieve cleaner energy. These actions are closely related, since the measures related to energy have a direct impact on the reduction of GHG emissions and, therefore, on climate change. Each chapter includes a description of the current situation, the objectives pursued, the measures proposed and a selection of indicators for proper monitoring. The measures stated require on numerous occasions the active participation of the different levels of administration, each of them in its corresponding area of competence.

_source.document_name: Spanish Climate Change And Clean Energy Strategy Horizon 2007- 2012 -2020
_source.document_description: The Spanish Climate Change and Clean Energy Strategy (EECCEL) horizon 2007-2012-2020 is part of the Spanish Sustainable Development Strategy (EEDS). The EECCEL includes different measures that contribute to sustainable development within the scope of climate change and clean energy.  This Strategy is based on the reference framework of the 'Spanish Strategy for the fulfilment of the objectives under the Kyoto Protocol', and it takes into account the measures and Programmes adopted by the Autonomous Communities.  The strategy has two chapters. The first one defines actions to fight against climate change and the second one, actions to achieve cleaner energy. Each chapter includes a description of the present situation, the objectives to be reached, the suggested measures and a selection of indicators for the corresponding follow-up.  The operational objectives are: - To ensure the reduction of GHG emissions in Spain, giving special importance to measures related to the energy sector. According to the national inventory, in 2005, emissions from energy process represented about 78.87% of total national emissions. - To contribute to sustainable development and the fulfilment of climate change commitments by strengthening the use of flexible project-based mechanisms. - To promote additional reduction measures in sectors concerned with diffuse pollution. - To apply the National Climate Change Adaptation Plan (NCCAP) so as to integrate adaptation measures and strategies in sectoral policies. - To increase public awareness with respect to clean energy and climate change. - To promote research, development and innovation in matters of climate change and clean energy. - To guarantee energy supply security by means of cleaner energies, mainly from renewable sources, achieving other environmental benefits (for example, air quality) and limiting the growth rate of external energy dependence. - To boost energy- and resource efficiency for companies and for end users.  The government has adopted a Plan of Urgent Measures (PMU), which together with the 2008-2012 Energy Saving and Efficiency Action Plan aims to consolidate the trend change of GHG emissions in Spain initiated in 2006.

_source.text: In 2005, total GHG emissions in Spain reached 440.6 Mt of CO₂-equivalent. This figure represents a 52.2% increase with respect to the emissions of the base year, or what is the same, almost 37.2 percentage points of excess over the commitment acquired in the Kyoto Protocol. The year 2005 was characterized by low hydroelectricity, an abnormally low contribution from nuclear generation and a high price of natural gas, but also by the beginning of a change in trend in the growth of primary energy demand. _source.text: INSTRUCTIONS OF THE PRESIDENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF INDONESIA
_source.document_name: Presidential Instruction No. 6 of 2013 on Suspension of New Licenses and Improving Forest Governance of Primary Forest and Peatland
_source.document_description: The first iteration of this instruction was issued in 2011 in order to implement commitments under the agreements in the Letter of Intent signed with the Kingdom of Norway in May 2011. The Instruction is intended to facilitate Indonesia's participation in internationally financed REDD activities and places a moratorium on clearance of primary peatland and forests within moratorium areas. The initial moratorium was extended by Presidential Instruction 6/2013. In 2019, President Joko Widodo signed Presidential Instruction 5/2019, making the moratorium on the clearance of primary forest and peatlands in moratorium areas permanent.

_source.text: Specifically to: 1. Minister of Forestry: a. Continue to postpone the issuance of new permits for primary natural forests and peatlands located in conservation forests, protected forests, production forests (limited production forests, regular/permanent production forests, convertible production forests) based on the Indicative Map for Suspension of New Permits. b. Continuing to improve governance policies for borrow-to-use permits and business permits for the use of timber forest products in natural forests. c. Continuing to increase the effectiveness of critical land management by taking into account good forest and peatland governance policies, including through ecosystem restoration. d. Revise the Indicative Map of Suspension of New Permits in forest areas every 6 (six) months. e. Establish an Indicative Map of Suspension of New Permits for primary natural forests and peatlands in the revised forest area.

_source.text: Presidency of the Republic Civil House Sub-chief for Legal Affairs
_source.document_name: Law 13.203 on Renegotiation of the hydrological risk of electricity generation and other matters related to electricity generation
_source.document_description:
The Law 13.203 adds some benefits for renewables, and changes a number of measures in the local electricity sector. It seeks to resolve Brazil's hydrological risk and create a new subsidy model to increase the attractiveness of renewable investments.
Under the new law, the hydropower generating companies can protect themselves against droughts with the permission to buy and stock renewable energy, in a similar fashion to reserve energy auctions. For generators of solar, wind, biomass and cogeneration power, the government can now also provide rebates of up to 50 per cent in transmission and distribution tariffs.
The law also lowers the usage fee for new plants of auto-generation renewable systems and facilitates reorganisation of shareholding of special purpose entities to drive investments in new renewable power plants.

_source.text: CHAPTER I
_source.document_name: Law 13.203 on Renegotiation of the hydrological risk of electricity generation and other matters related to electricity generation
_source.document_description:
The Law 13.203 adds some benefits for renewables, and changes a number of measures in the local electricity sector. It seeks to resolve Brazil's hydrological risk and create a new subsidy model to increase the attractiveness of renewable investments.
Under the new law, the hydropower generating companies can protect themselves against droughts with the permission to buy and stock renewable energy, in a similar fashion to reserve energy auctions. For generators of solar, wind, biomass and cogeneration power, the government can now also provide rebates of up to 50 per cent in transmission and distribution tariffs.
The law also lowers the usage fee for new plants of auto-generation renewable systems and facilitates reorganisation of shareholding of special purpose entities to drive investments in new renewable power plants.
